creditline: The John E. and Marion Andrus III Fund
inscription: LLC in blue pencil: 186 | verso LLC in purple pencil: 1969. | verso LLC in pencil (various hands): Duke (?) 182e / II = Sch 186 II 1977 / K9420
markings: verso LLC stamped in purple: NACHLASS / E.L. KIRCHNER / R 186 II | verso LLC stamped in black: EWK | verso LRQ stamped in purple: Unverkäuflich E L Kirchner
text: When Ernst Ludwig Kirchner moved to Berlin in 1911, he found himself in a glistening yet anxious world: electric lights, department stores, and crowds of working women who unsettled conventional moral codes. He responded with a series of prints whose agitated lines and compressed space convey the energy of modern life. Here a coquette offers herself to a dapper man. She embodies the ambivalence of modern freedom: she is economically independent yet trapped within a system of exchange.
title: Coquette Offering Herself
